title: collinearityR-vignette
text: use data set mpg ggplot2 package explore multicollinearity tools collinearityR. dataset contains 234 observations 11 variables.
code: data <- ggplot2::mpg dim(data) #> [1] 234  11 data #> # A tibble: 234 x 11 #>    manufacturer model      displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    class #>    <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> #>  1 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 auto~ f        18    29 p     comp~ #>  2 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 manu~ f        21    29 p     comp~ #>  3 audi         a4           2    2008     4 manu~ f        20    31 p     comp~ #>  4 audi         a4           2    2008     4 auto~ f        21    30 p     comp~ #>  5 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 auto~ f        16    26 p     comp~ #>  6 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 manu~ f        18    26 p     comp~ #>  7 audi         a4           3.1  2008     6 auto~ f        18    27 p     comp~ #>  8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 manu~ 4        18    26 p     comp~ #>  9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 auto~ 4        16    25 p     comp~ #> 10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008     4 manu~ 4        20    28 p     comp~ #> # ... with 224 more rows

what: Correlation Matrix and its Longer Form
title: collinearityR-vignette
text: corr_matrix() allows calculate Pearson correlation coefficients numeric variables. Moreover, can round outcome desired decimals. output generic correlation matrix longer form, can decide form can use directly plot heatmap without data manipulation. example, can calculate correlation matrix longer form using numerical columns mpg.

title: collinearityR-vignette
text: corr_heatmap() allows visualize correlations making heatmap. function plots data color-encoded Pearson correlation matrix using longer form output returned corr_matrix(). can individually specify colors negative positive correlations. example, can plot heatmap numerical columns mpg.

what: Data Frame and Bar Chart of Variance Inflation Factors (VIF)
title: collinearityR-vignette
text: vif_bar_plot() allows perform linear regression, calculate VIF scores plot VIF scores using single function. output list containing tibble includes VIF scores bar chart VIF scores alongside specified threshold explanatory variable linear regression model. visualization VIF scores alongside adjustable thershold helps quick identification multicollinear variables. example can calculate visualize VIF scores linear regression using columns mpg.
code: vif_bar_plot(c("displ", "cyl", "hwy"), "year", data, 5)[[1]] #> # A tibble: 3 x 2 #>   vif_score explanatory_var #>       <dbl> <chr>           #> 1      7.88 displ           #> 2      7.76 cyl             #> 3      2.53 hwy vif_bar_plot(c("displ", "cyl", "hwy"), "year", data, 5)[[2]]

what: Multicollinearity Identification based on Pearson Coefficient and VIF Scores
title: collinearityR-vignette
text: col_identify() allows eliminate explanatory variables linear regression model incorporating Pearson’s coefficient VIF scores. output data frame containing Pearson’s coefficient, VIF scores explanatory variables suggested elimination. multicollinearity detected, output empty data frame. function employs corr_matrix() vif_bar_plot() process. Example, can incorporate Pearson’s coefficient VIF scores linear regression model using columns mpg.
code: col_identify(data, c("displ", "cyl", "hwy", "cty"), "year",              corr_min = -0.8, corr_max = 0.8,              vif_limit = 5) #> Joining, by = "variable1" #> # A tibble: 3 x 5 #> # Groups:   pair [3] #>   variable correlation rounded_corr pair      vif_score #>   <chr>          <dbl>        <dbl> <list>        <dbl> #> 1 cty            0.956         0.96 <chr [2]>     13.9  #> 2 cty           -0.806        -0.81 <chr [2]>     13.9  #> 3 cyl            0.930         0.93 <chr [2]>      8.17

title: Contributing to collinearityR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to collinearityR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to collinearityR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("UBC-MDS/collinearityR_tool", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to collinearityR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to collinearityR
text: Please note collinearityR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Identify Multicollinearity Issues
text: Identify multicollinearity issues correlation, VIF, visualizations. package designed beginners R want identify multicollinearity issues applying simple function. automates process building longer form correlation matrix, creating correlation heat map identifying pairwise highly correlated variables. python version package also progress development.

title: Identify Multicollinearity Issues
text: following four functions collinearityR package: corr_matrix: function returns generic longer form correlation matrix numerical variables data frame. corr_heatmap: function returns correlation heatmap given dataframe. vif_bar_plot: function returns list containing data frame Variable Inflation Factors (VIF) bar chart VIFs explanatory variable multiple linear regression model. col_identify: function identifies multicollinearity based highly correlated pairs (using Pearson coefficient) VIF values exceeding threshold.

title: Identify Multicollinearity Issues
text: R ecosystem contains many tools necessary conduct linear regression. However, tools analyze multicollinearity visually using Pearson’s coefficient VIF. process also requires intermediate knowledge R manipulate correlation matrix suitable format. package allow users less experience conduct analysis. cor(): function part base r. creates correlation matrix variables using Pearson’s coefficient. Documentation cor() can accessed . ggplot: one commonly used plotting packages. collinearityR package relies ggplot create heatmap plots. car: car package necessary VIF calculations. documentation VIF function can found .

what:
Identifies multicollinearity using
Pearson's coefficient and suggests the variable
with the highest VIF score out of the correlated pair
for elimination. — col_identify
title:
Identifies multicollinearity using
Pearson's coefficient and suggests the variable
with the highest VIF score out of the correlated pair
for elimination. — col_identify
text: Returns DataFrame containing Pearson's coefficient, VIF explanatory variables suggested elimination. empty dataframe means multicollinearity detected.

title:
Identifies multicollinearity using
Pearson's coefficient and suggests the variable
with the highest VIF score out of the correlated pair
for elimination. — col_identify
code: col_identify(df, X, y, corr_min = -0.8, corr_max = 0.8, vif_limit = 4)

title:
Identifies multicollinearity using
Pearson's coefficient and suggests the variable
with the highest VIF score out of the correlated pair
for elimination. — col_identify
text: df input dataframe X Explanatory variables (vector characters) y Response variable (single vector) corr_min (optional) decimal number serves threshold selecting pair. Pearson coefficient value. Default set -0.8. corr_max (optional) decimal number serves threshold selecting pair. Pearson coefficient value. Default set 0.8. vif_limit (optional) decimal number serves threshold selecting pair. VIF value. Default set 4.

title:
Identifies multicollinearity using
Pearson's coefficient and suggests the variable
with the highest VIF score out of the correlated pair
for elimination. — col_identify
code: col_identify(iris, c("Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length"),              "Petal.Width", vif_limit = 0, corr_max = 0.3, corr_min = -0.3) #> Joining, by = "variable1" #> # A tibble: 2 x 5 #> # Groups:   pair [1] #>   variable     correlation rounded_corr pair      vif_score #>   <chr>              <dbl>        <dbl> <list>        <dbl> #> 1 Sepal.Width       -0.428        -0.43 <chr [2]>      1.22 #> 2 Petal.Length      -0.428        -0.43 <chr [2]>      1.22

what:
Returns a list containing a tibble that includes Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) score and
a bar chart for the VIF scores alongside the specified threshold for each explanatory variable
in a linear regression model. — vif_bar_plot

in a linear regression model. — vif_bar_plot
text: Returns list containing tibble includes Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) score bar chart VIF scores alongside specified threshold explanatory variable linear regression model.

text: x vector names explanatory variables. y string specifying response variable. df tibble containing data. thresh integer specifying threshold.

title:
Returns a list containing a tibble that includes Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) score and
a bar chart for the VIF scores alongside the specified threshold for each explanatory variable
in a linear regression model. — vif_bar_plot
code: vif_bar_plot(c("Sepal.Width", "Sepal.Length"), "Petal.Width", iris, 5) #> [[1]] #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #>   vif_score explanatory_var #>       <dbl> <chr>           #> 1      1.01 Sepal.Width     #> 2      1.01 Sepal.Length    #>  #> [[2]]  #>
